text: I think especially if you're newer in your PM career, they just have a really great organization. And I think it's a great place to learn how to PM. Also their product, it's a huge scaled product. And so it's complicated to build in. So I think it's a great place to really understand second order systems and systems thinking.
speaker: Nickey Skarstad
context: Lenny asks Nickey about her experience at Shopify and whether she'd recommend it to other PMs. Nickey explains that while the platform role wasn't the right fit for her personally, she still thinks Shopify is an excellent company for product managers to work at. She's discussing what makes Shopify valuable for PM career development and skill building.
text_ko: 특히 프로덕트 매니저(PM)로 경력이 아직 짧다면 그 회사는 조직이 정말 잘 되어 있어요. PM을 배우기 좋은 곳이에요. 그리고 그 회사의 제품은 규모가 엄청난 제품(huge scaled product)이라서 구축이 복잡해요. 그래서 세컨드 오더 시스템(second-order systems)과 시스템 사고(systems thinking)를 제대로 이해하기에 아주 좋은 곳이라고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得特别是如果你在产品经理这条路上还比较新的话，他们公司组织架构真的很不错。我觉得是个学怎么做产品经理的好地方。还有就是他们的产品，规模特别大，所以在里面开发是很复杂的。我觉得在那里真的能深入理解二阶系统(second order systems)和系统性思维(systems thinking)。
text_es: Creo que especialmente si estás empezando tu carrera como PM, tienen una organización realmente sólida. Y me parece un lugar excelente para aprender a ser PM. Además su producto está a una escala enorme. Y por eso es complicado desarrollar ahí. Entonces creo que es un lugar genial para entender de verdad los sistemas de segundo orden (second order systems) y el pensamiento sistémico (systems thinking).
key_sentence: It's a great place to understand second order systems and systems thinking.

text: I actually went through my calendar and I changed the colors of all of the meetings on my calendar to red, yellow, and green after I had the meeting. And I looked. And basically if it was yellow, I was like, okay. It was a fine meeting. My energy was baseline. If it was red, I was either bored or I was stressed, or I was not having a good time. And if it was green, it gave me energy and I felt excited and I wanted to keep working on that.
speaker: Nickey Skarstad
context: Lenny asks Nickey for advice on how to know if a role or company isn't a good fit. Nickey shares a practical technique she used while at Shopify to evaluate whether her work was energizing her. She describes a color-coding system to track her energy levels after meetings as a way to objectively assess job satisfaction and determine if a role is right for you.
text_ko: 사실 저는 캘린더를 쭉 훑으면서 미팅이 끝난 뒤에 모든 미팅을 빨강·노랑·초록으로 색을 바꿔놨어요. 그리고 보니까 기본적으로 노랑이면 그냥 무난한 미팅이었어요. 에너지도 평상시 수준이었고요. 빨강이면 지루했거나 스트레스를 받았거나 기분이 안 좋았고, 초록이면 에너지가 생기고 신나서 그 일을 더 이어가고 싶더라고요.
text_zh: 我真的把我的日历翻了一遍，把所有开完的会议都标上了颜色——红色、黄色、绿色。然后我发现，黄色的会议就是那种还行吧，没什么感觉，就是正常状态。红色的会议要么让我觉得无聊，要么压力特别大，反正就是很难受。绿色的会议就不一样了，开完特别有劲儿，很兴奋，还想继续干下去。
text_es: Decidí revisar mi calendario y cambié los colores de todas las reuniones a rojo, amarillo y verde después de tenerlas. Y me puse a analizar los resultados. Básicamente, si era amarillo, era como "bueno, estuvo bien." La reunión fue normal, mi energía se quedó igual. Si era rojo, o me aburrí muchísimo o me estresé, o la pasé fatal. Y si era verde, me dio energía, me emocioné y me dieron ganas de seguir trabajando en eso.
key_sentence: Green meetings gave me energy and excitement to keep working.

text: I've seen a lot of director level people through my career who will try to work on strategy in a vacuum alone. They'll write a document and they'll be like, "Okay, team. Here's what we're doing. Here's our strategy." And it never goes well. And it doesn't go well. It might be the right strategy, but because you did not bring people along on that journey to come up with it, they did not feel like they had a hand in crafting it themselves.
speaker: Nickey Skarstad
context: Lenny asks Nickey about her approach to setting vision, translating it into goals, and executing on those goals - something she's known for doing well. Nickey is explaining her first principle for strategy work, which is to involve the team in the process rather than working alone. She's describing a common mistake she's observed where leaders create strategy in isolation.
vocabulary_highlights: work on strategy in a vacuum
bring people along on that journey
had a hand in crafting it
text_ko: 제 경력 동안 혼자서만 전략을 고민하는 디렉터급(director level) 분들을 많이 봐왔어요. 문서를 하나 만들어서는 “자, 팀. 우리가 이렇게 할 거예요. 이게 우리의 전략입니다.” 하고 던져놓죠. 그리고 잘 풀리는 경우는 거의 없어요. 설령 전략 자체는 옳을지라도, 사람들을 그 과정에 함께 끌어들이지 않으면 스스로 그 전략을 만들었다는 느낌을 받지 못해요.
text_zh: 我这些年见过不少总监级别的人，喜欢自己一个人闷头搞战略。他们写完文档就跟团队说："好了大家，我们就这么干，这就是我们的战略。"结果从来没成功过。确实成功不了啊。可能战略本身没问题，但你没有让大家参与到制定过程中来，他们就觉得这事跟自己没关系，不是自己参与做出来的。
text_es: He visto a muchos directores a lo largo de mi carrera que intentan trabajar la estrategia completamente solos, como en una burbuja. Se ponen a escribir un documento y después llegan con el equipo y les dicen: "Bueno, equipo. Esto es lo que vamos a hacer. Esta es nuestra estrategia." Y nunca funciona bien. Por más que sea la estrategia correcta, como no involucraste a la gente en ese proceso para desarrollarla, no sienten que tuvieron participación en crearla.
key_sentence: Directors should not work on strategy in a vacuum alone.

text: And I actually think that had they launched experiences inside of the Etsy style of organizational structure, it never would've succeeded because it had such a unique business need, and it needed its own process and ways of building product, et cetera. And because they sort of, hate to say wall it off, because it wasn't fully walled off, but because they gave it its own space and its own structure, it allowed it to succeed because they were able to fund it in the right way, give it the resources that it needed, et cetera.
speaker: Nickey Skarstad
context: Lenny asks Nickey about different organizational structures for product teams, comparing functional versus GM (general manager) models. Nickey is explaining why the GM structure worked well for Airbnb Experiences, where she worked as the first product manager. She's contrasting how Airbnb's GM approach for Experiences differed from Etsy's functional structure and why that was crucial for the new product's success.
vocabulary_highlights: fund it in the right way
text_ko: 솔직히 그 경험들을 Etsy 스타일의 조직 구조(Etsy-style organizational structure) 안에서 론칭했더라면 성공하지 못했을 거라고 생각해요. 그건 비즈니스 요구가 워낙 특이해서 자체 프로세스(process)와 제품을 만드는 방식(ways of building product) 같은 것들이 따로 필요했거든요. '벽을 쳐놨다'고 말하기는 좀 그런데(wall it off), 완전히 분리된 건 아니었지만, 따로 공간과 구조를 줘서 적절한 방식으로 자금을 지원받고(fund it) 필요한 자원도 받게 해 준 덕분에 성공할 수 있었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果他们当时在Etsy那套组织架构下推出体验产品，肯定做不成，因为这个业务太特殊了，需要有自己的流程和产品开发方式。虽然不能说是完全隔离吧，但他们给了这个项目独立的空间和架构，这样才能成功，因为可以用合适的方式给资金，提供需要的资源什么的。
text_es: Y la verdad es que creo que si hubieran lanzado las experiencias dentro de la estructura organizacional típica de Etsy, nunca habría funcionado porque tenía necesidades de negocio muy particulares, y necesitaba sus propios procesos y formas de desarrollar producto, y todo eso. Y como que... no me gusta decir que lo separaron completamente, porque no fue así, pero como le dieron su propio espacio y su propia estructura, eso permitió que tuviera éxito porque pudieron financiarlo de la manera correcta, darle los recursos que necesitaba, y todo eso.
key_sentence: Giving it its own space allowed it to succeed.

text: And so we actually put more friction in the onboarding flow to help to start to solve for that. So we actually slowed you down. We made you be more thoughtful about what you were listing. And by doing that, we actually helped you get to a first sale faster. And so that was another good example of a quality metric that we used, which was, I think it was first sale in seven days.
speaker: Nickey Skarstad
context: Lenny asks about quality metrics that help maintain product quality. Nickey is sharing an example from Etsy where she worked on seller onboarding. She explains how they discovered that optimizing purely for shop openings actually hurt downstream metrics - sellers weren't getting their first sale quickly enough. The solution was counterintuitive: adding friction to make sellers more thoughtful about their listings, which improved their success rate.
text_ko: 그래서 그걸 해결하기 위해 온보딩 플로우(onboarding flow)에 오히려 마찰을 더 넣었어요. 그래서 실제로 속도를 늦추고 사용자가 무엇을 올릴지 더 신중하게 생각하게 만들었어요. 그렇게 하니까 오히려 첫 판매에 더 빨리 도달할 수 있게 도왔어요. 그게 우리가 쓴 또 다른 좋은 품질 지표(quality metric)의 예였는데, 아마 7일 내 첫 판매(first sale in seven days)였던 것 같아요.
text_zh: 所以我们其实在用户引导流程(onboarding flow)里故意增加了一些阻力来解决这个问题。我们就是让你慢下来，让你更仔细地思考你要发布什么东西。这样做的结果是，你反而能更快地完成第一笔交易。这就是我们用的另一个很好的质量指标(quality metric)的例子，好像是七天内完成首单这个指标。
text_es: Y entonces lo que hicimos fue meter más fricción en el proceso de incorporación (onboarding) para empezar a solucionar eso. O sea, te ralentizamos a propósito. Te hicimos pensar más detenidamente en lo que estabas publicando. Y haciendo eso, en realidad te ayudamos a conseguir tu primera venta más rápido. Y ese fue otro buen ejemplo de una métrica de calidad que usamos, que era, creo que era primera venta en siete días.
key_sentence: We put more friction in onboarding to solve for that.

text: The decisions you make today will affect tomorrow's decisions and your ability to build on your decisions that you made today. And this feels very existential and meta, but why it's important is that, especially when you're building product, is there's a cost associated with your time of everything you build. Especially when you're building marketplaces or anything with UGC content. When you make a change today, and it impacts every single user in your ecosystem that then is going to act on that change, it's really hard to make those changes later.
speaker: Nickey Skarstad
context: Lenny asks Nickey to explain her concept of second order decision-making, which she has written about in her newsletter. Nickey is defining what second order thinking means - the ability to think beyond immediate decisions to understand how today's choices will impact future decisions and the broader system. She's explaining why this is particularly important for product managers working on complex systems like marketplaces.
text_ko: 오늘 내리는 결정은 내일의 결정뿐 아니라, 오늘 한 결정을 바탕으로 더 쌓아갈 수 있는 능력에도 영향을 줘요. 존재론적이고 메타하게 느껴지긴 하지만, 중요한 이유는 특히 제품을 개발할 때 만든 모든 것에는 시간이라는 비용이 따르기 때문이에요. 특히 마켓플레이스(marketplaces)나 사용자 생성 콘텐츠(UGC)를 다루는 서비스일수록 더 그래요. 오늘 어떤 변경을 하면 그 변경이 생태계(ecosystem) 안의 모든 사용자에게 영향을 주고, 그 사람들이 그 변경에 맞춰 행동하게 되죠. 그래서 나중에 그걸 바꾸는 건 정말 어려워요.
text_zh: 你今天做的决策会影响明天的决策，也会影响你在今天决策基础上继续发展的能力。这听起来很哲学很抽象，但为什么重要呢？特别是做产品的时候，你构建的每样东西都有时间成本。尤其是做市场平台(marketplace)或者任何涉及用户生成内容(UGC)的产品时。你今天做一个改动，会影响到生态系统里的每个用户，然后他们都会基于这个改动去行动，这样一来后面再想改就特别难了。
text_es: Las decisiones que tomes hoy van a impactar las decisiones de mañana y tu capacidad para construir sobre lo que decidiste hoy. Y sí, suena muy existencial y abstracto, pero es súper importante porque, sobre todo cuando estás desarrollando producto, cada cosa que construyes te cuesta tiempo. Especialmente cuando estás armando marketplaces o cualquier cosa con contenido UGC (user-generated content). Cuando haces un cambio hoy que afecta a cada usuario de tu ecosistema y todos van a reaccionar a ese cambio, después es re difícil modificar esas cosas.
key_sentence: Today's decisions have a cost associated with UGC content.
